citations.narrative:
Since the last inspection, many ducks have been found deceased and/or are missing within their fully overhead netted
outdoor primary enclosure. At the last inspection, 217 ducks were present and at this inspection 234 ducks were
inventoried. Since the last inspection, 39 ducks were hatched with 15 documented deaths of various causes listed. Seven
ducks are currently not accounted for and are therefore missing. Facilities that do not contain the birds securely and/or
restrict other animals from entering can negatively affect the welfare of the birds contained within, such as animals
escaping, being predated upon, injured, etc. Correct by ensuring that housing facilities for birds are designed and
constructed so that they protect the birds from injury, restrict other animals from entering, and contain the birds securely in
accordance with 3.150(a).

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
Since the last inspection, one bald eagle was transported on two separate occasions for exhibition (New Orleans, LA and
Atlanta, GA) without submitting itineraries containing the exhibition location information to the Deputy Administrator.
Instead, only the overnight address location was provided. Itineraries that do not include all the required information can
make it difficult for Animal Care to track animal exhibitions and perform necessary inspections to ensure animal welfare at
traveling sites. All licensees that exhibit animals overnight at any location other than the person's approved site, must
provide an itinerary to Animal Care at least 48 hours prior to travel which includes the names, dates, and locations where
the animals will travel, be housed, and be exhibited in addition to the name of the person exhibiting the animals and the
required animal information (name or ID number, species, sex, and age).

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live birds.
citations.narrative:
A bald eagle has continued to be transported back and forth to a second location, per a facility representative, that is not
contained in a transport enclosure that meets AWA requirements. The bald eagle is loaded and tethered onto a perch
attached to a sliding apparatus inside the cargo area of a sport utility vehicle. Additionally, this same bald eagle has been
transported in a transport enclosure for longer trips, that does not meet AWA standards since it does not have projecting
rims, live animal stickers or meet the ventilation requirements. This manner of transport does not protect the bird from
injury. It's important for the bird's safety to be transported in an appropriate enclosure that completely contains the bird,
with no sharp edges or points, can be easily and quickly removed in an emergency, have appropriate ventilation, a solid
leak-proof bottom or a removable, leak-proof collection tray, and if not permanently affixed to the conveyance, has
projecting rims with handholds, be marked with the words "Live Animals" and arrows to indicate the correct upright
position in letters not less than 1 inch high. Birds that are transported from their facility must be contained in compliant
transport enclosures.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by MARCH 22, 2026, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
CODY YAGER, Avian Field Specialist n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
Since the last inspection, many ducks have been found deceased and/or are missing within their fully overhead netted 
outdoor primary enclosure. At the last inspection, 217 ducks were present and at this inspection 234 ducks were 
inventoried. Since the last inspection, 39 ducks were hatched with 15 documented deaths of various causes listed. Seven 
ducks are currently not accounted for and are therefore missing. Facilities that do not contain the birds securely and/or 
restrict other animals from entering can negatively affect the welfare of the birds contained within, such as animals 
escaping, being predated upon, injured, etc. Correct by ensuring that housing facilities for birds are designed and 
constructed so that they protect the birds from injury, restrict other animals from entering, and contain the birds securely in 
accordance with 3.150(a). 
2.126(c)(1)(iii) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
Since the last inspection, one bald eagle was transported on two separate occasions for exhibition (New Orleans, LA and 
Atlanta, GA) without submitting itineraries containing the exhibition location information to the Deputy Administrator. 
Instead, only the overnight address location was provided. Itineraries that do not include all the required information can 
make it difficult for Animal Care to track animal exhibitions and perform necessary inspections to ensure animal welfare at 
traveling sites. All licensees that exhibit animals overnight at any location other than the person's approved site, must 
provide an itinerary to Animal Care at least 48 hours prior to travel which includes the names, dates, and locations where 
the animals will travel, be housed, and be exhibited in addition to the name of the person exhibiting the animals and the 
required animal information (name or ID number, species, sex, and age). 
3.162(a)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live birds. 
A bald eagle has continued to be transported back and forth to a second location, per a facility representative, that is not 
contained in a transport enclosure that meets AWA requirements. The bald eagle is loaded and tethered onto a perch 
attached to a sliding apparatus inside the cargo area of a sport utility vehicle. Additionally, this same bald eagle has been 
transported in a transport enclosure for longer trips, that does not meet AWA standards since it does not have projecting 
rims, live animal stickers or meet the ventilation requirements. This manner of transport does not protect the bird from

injury. It's important for the bird's safety to be transported in an appropriate enclosure that completely contains the bird, 
with no sharp edges or points, can be easily and quickly removed in an emergency, have appropriate ventilation, a solid 
leak-proof bottom or a removable, leak-proof collection tray, and if not permanently affixed to the conveyance, has 
projecting rims with handholds, be marked with the words "Live Animals" and arrows to indicate the correct upright 
position in letters not less than 1 inch high. Birds that are transported from their facility must be contained in compliant 
transport enclosures. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by MARCH 22, 2026, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
CODY YAGER, Avian Field Specialist n

species.common: BARN OWL / WESTERN BARN OWL / AMERICAN BARN OWL /
